newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish shares fall, brief rebound expected.
newsitem.headline: Polish shares fall, brief rebound expected.

text.p: Polish shares fell in higher turnover for the fifth time running but analysts expected a brief rebound on revived demand following the market's 6.3 percent slide from its October 9 high of 15,078.7 points.
The main market's WIG index fell 1.7 percent, to 14,133.4, and turnover rose 5.3 percent to 103.2 million zlotys ($36.8 million) on both markets as 55 issues fell, 10 rose and 15 were flat.

"We are likely to have a brief one or two-session rebound as the market has already fallen significantly and some prices might look attractive again," said Pawel Tarnowski, an analyst at Raiffeisen Capital and Investment Polska.
Some analysts said a downride to 14,000 or 13,500 points of the WIG index or stabilisation was likely as the market looked weak after its 90-percent rise since the start of the year.
Some analysts said banks, WIG's heavyweights, were the most vulnerable to profit-taking, or at least losing steam, after their growth this year.
But some saw a growth potential in the market and expected it to climb up to 15,500-16,000 points in late November or early December.

Traders said Zywiec brewer plunged 10 percent in a one-million-zloty ($0.4 million) turnover after the company said it was shutting down one of its breweries and sacking 145 of its 990 employees and after it showed unspectacular September earnings.
Mass privatisation NFI units rose 0.3 percent in a 16.6-million zloty ($5.9 million) turnover in the regular session and rose 3.4 percent in 21.7-million-zloty ($7.8 million) continuous trade.
